awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020: Investigating Feedbacks Between Guppy Host Behavior and Gyrodactylid Parasite Evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. This research investigates the interactions between animal social behavior and parasite adaptation. When animals socially interact often, parasites (such as viruses or worms) transmit between animal hosts more easily. Faster transmission may lead parasites to change and become deadlier to hosts. In turn, animals may behaviorally avoid infected individuals, reducing the spread of deadly parasitic infections. This research tests how host behavior and parasite evolution interact using mathematical models and laboratory experiments with a fish host and worm parasite. The results of this research may prove important for fish aquaculture where the worm parasite annually causes a great deal of economic damage. Further, this research addresses fundamental scientific questions of how host behavior interacts with parasite evolution. Answers to these questions are important for the health of many species, including humans. Students at multiple academic levels will participate in this research. Particularly, the fellow will train high school students from underrepresented groups in the Pittsburgh area to help with the research. This valuable research experience and the fellow’s mentoring will improve students’ prospects for college admissions.

This research advances theoretical and empirical understanding of the interactions of host contact behavior and parasite evolution. The co-sponsor will train the fellow in mathematical theory. Specifically, theoretical models will link the individual host-level course of infection to the population-level epidemic dynamics, an emerging area of epidemiological theory. This framework will predict the interactions of plastic host contact behavior and parasite deadliness (virulence) evolution. The sponsor will train the fellow in empirical work with Trindadian guppies and their flatworm (gyrodactylid) parasites. This system is particularly suitable since guppies alter their social behavior to avoid other guppies infected with flatworms. In addition, flatworm numbers on individual guppies can be measured non-invasively to track the individual-host course of infection in addition to population-level epidemics. The researchers predict that more social contact between hosts will select for deadlier parasites. In turn, deadlier parasites should cause a greater host response to decrease social contact. These interactions are hypothesized to lead to cycling of host social behavior and parasite evolution. As part of this work the fellow will train undergraduate and high school students in research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Infectious diseases are caused by viruses, bacteria, worms, or other parasites that can evolve very rapidly. Because these parasites can cause great harm to humans and species of human interest, such as endangered species or livestock, it is critical for us to track, understand, and predict parasite evolution.

Hosts, on the other hand, usually cannot evolve as rapidly. For example, human hosts have much longer generation times than a flu virus, allowing the flu virus to evolve much more rapidly than humans. However, hosts can typically respond rapidly to parasites by changing their behavior. Thus, much of the interactive struggle between hosts and disease likely occurs as parasites evolve, hosts change their behavior in response, parasites evolve in response to host behavior, etcetera. While it is difficult to make any clear conclusions about the simultaneous interactions of host behavior and parasite evolution, such understanding is critical for our ability to understand and manage infectious diseases.

I addressed this vital question with new theory and experimental work in an ideal tropical fish system. Trinidadian guppies shoal for protection from larger fish. While shoaling, they contact each other, providing opportunities for transmission of a worm parasite that lives on their skin. Guppies attempt to “social distance” in the presence of serious infections to avoid getting infected themselves. The worm, in turn, can evolve to reproduce faster; faster reproduction carries an advantage in terms of better chances to transmit but a disadvantage in terms of increased deadliness so that the worm risks losing its fish host before it has a chance to transmit to its next host. I developed new, mathematical theory capturing how guppy host behavior influences worm parasite evolution and vice versa. I provided extensive data to my mathematical model, which then predicted the direction and extent to which guppy host behavior was influencing worm parasite behavior and vice versa.

One key prediction from the model was that more social guppy hosts would have deadlier parasites. The model clarifies that this result arises because social hosts give more opportunities for transmission, their high sociality favors worm parasites that reproduce fast and transmit well despite killing fast. Less social hosts, on the other hand, force worm parasites to reproduce more slowly and keep their fish host alive longer to wait for the opportunity to transmit to the next fish. In collaboration with an international team, I tested these model predictions by measuring the deadliness of parasites from four different wild guppy populations, differing in the degree of guppy host sociality. The model correctly predicted that the more social guppy populations had deadlier parasites (approximately twice as deadly), even predicting the precise degree of parasite deadliness with surprisingly good accuracy (within approximately 10%). These results may be important for many other host-parasite systems. For example, social distancing in humans should select for reduced deadliness of certain human diseases.

I also integrated scientific training and outreach as complementary parts of my research program. While conducting this research, I trained three Ph.D., four undergraduate, and one high school student in laboratory techniques, statistical analysis, scientific writing, computer programming, and other key skills. In addition, I have guest lectured annually for local, middle school science classes. Further, I co-developed and presented a physical demonstration of robotic hosts transmitting a hypothetical disease for science outreach, which I presented at a farmer’s market and has been presented elsewhere by my collaborators. Lastly, I was interviewed regarding my research on host social behavior and parasite evolution, helping spread my findings through articles on several popular science websites.
